steps: Wash your hands before touching the wound.
Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth to stop the bleeding.
Clean the wound with water only. Avoid using alcohol or iodine.
Apply an antibiotic ointment and cover it with a sterile bandage.
Seek medical help if the bleeding is severe or doesn't stop.
Cool the burn under running water for 10–15 minutes.
Do not apply ice, butter, or creams.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-stick bandage.
Take over-the-counter pain relief if needed.
Seek medical attention if blisters appear or if it covers a large area.
Sit upright and lean slightly forward.
Pinch the soft part of the nose continuously for 10–15 minutes.
Breathe through your mouth while pinching.
Apply a cold compress to the nose or cheeks.
Seek medical help if bleeding lasts more than 20 minutes.
Ask the person if they’re choking and if they can speak.
If they can't breathe or speak, perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Repeat until the object is expelled or the person becomes unresponsive.
If unresponsive, start CPR and call emergency services.
Help the person lie down and elevate their legs.
Loosen tight clothing.
Check for breathing and responsiveness.
Do not give food or drink until fully recovered.
Call emergency services if they do not regain consciousness within a minute.
Sit the person upright and stay calm.
Help them use their inhaler (usually 1–2 puffs every 30–60 seconds, up to 10 puffs).
Call emergency services if there's no improvement.
Keep the person calm and reassured until help arrives.
Call emergency services immediately.
Use an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if available.
Help the person lie down and elevate their legs if possible.
Do not give them food or drink.
Perform CPR if they stop breathing.
Keep the injured area still and supported.
Apply a cold pack to reduce swelling.
Do not attempt to straighten or move the broken bone.
Cover any open wounds with a sterile dressing.
Seek immediate medical help.
